bibl.title: Letter from Selskar M. Gunn to Frederick F. Russell, August 29, 1922

div1.p: Gunn reports to Russell on yellow fever and public health conditions in the Ivory Coast, Africa.

div1.head: Letter from Selskar M. Gunn to Frederick F. Russell, August 29, 1922
div1.opener:
COPY
INTERNATIONAL HEALTH BOARD
Paris
August 29, 1922
Dr. F. F. Russell,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway
New York City
Dear Russell:
div1.p:
I am in receipt of a cablegram from you relative to yellow fever
at Grand Bassam, Ivory Coast. I am sending you tonight cablegram, copy of
which I append.

It so happens that Mr. Antonetti, Lieutenant-Governor of the Ivory
Coast is in Paris and I have had an interview with him today. He states
that the Medical Service in Grand Bassam is first class and that he does not
believe there are any cases hidden. He has a physician on his staff trained
at the Pasteur Institute in Paris. All cases are being immediately isolated
and out of contact of mosquitoes. He would be very pleased to receive some
of the Noguchi serum for treatment and vaccine for immunisation and promises
to have his physician make a report on the use of this material if its need
is still indicated when it arrives. I told him that I did not know if it
would be possible to send these biological products at this time.

According to Mr. Antonetti yellow fever has not been present in
the Ivory Coast for years; he did not specify how many. The population of
Grand Bassam consists of 150 Europeans and 6,000 negroes. Mr. Antonetti
states that mosquitoes are not found in other parts of this colony and that
therefore the disease cannot spread within the territory. he states that he
has under his direction a well trained sanitary squad of native men who
inspect the city from the point of view of mosquito suppression.

He states further that the two big problems to be met in connection
with mosquito control consist in the tens of thousands of crab holes which
become full of water and excellent breeding places for mosquitoes. These
are located very near the town and in the opinion of Mr. Antonetti breed
yellow fever mosquitoes. His other problem is in connection with sandy soil
near the town where heavy rain stands in pools up to two weeks and present
a grave difficulty as far as draining is concerned.

Mr. Antonetti indicates that the physicians at his disposal are
thoroughly conversant with yellow fever control. He is in conference with
the Pasteur Institute in Paris. Mr. Antonetti further believes that yellow
fever of a very mild form is probably endemic amongst the natives who
constitute a reservoir of yellow fever virus and which for some obscure
reason becomes virulent for Europeans from time to time.

Mr. Antonetti would be pleased if you would send him directly to
Grand Bassam, Cote d'Ivoire, reprints of yellow fever literature and reports
of the International Health Board for his medical staff. I doubt if the
French Colonial Office would be willing at this time to have a representative
of the I.H.B. go to the Ivory Coast, but, of course, have not discussed the
matter with anybody as I do not know whether such a thing might be possible
for the I.H.B. I have a slight impression that the situation is actually
worse than reported to me. The Colonial Office here has just received a
cablegram announcing a death from yellow fever at Anetcheou, in Togo. Mr.
Antonetti states that ships are constantly coming to Grand Bassam from various
points on the west coast of Africa.

If I receive any other information I shall send it to you by mail,
and by cable if it seems important.
div1.closer: Yours very sincerely, (Signed) Selskar M. Gunn SMG/OM
